snippet: According to an analysis by the New York Civil Liberties Union, the police seized one gun for every 879 street stops in 2011, compared with one gun for every 266 stops in 2003.
abstract: Critics of the New York City Police Department's stop-and-frisk tactics point to New York City Liberties Union analysis showing falling gun recovery rate ACLU says is a sign that the department is stopping too many innocent people in minority neighborhoods; police officials say drop in numbers indicates the effectiveness of the tactic.

byline.original: By AL BAKER and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

lead_paragraph: According to an analysis by the New York Civil Liberties Union, the police seized one gun for every 879 street stops in 2011, compared with one gun for every 266 stops in 2003.

headline.seo: Police Stop-and-Frisk Tactic Had Lower Gun Recovery Rate in 2011
